image.altText: A drone shot of people on an island

props.synopsis: The island of Aorigi is a remote dot on the map south-east of the Solomon Islands' capital. And here on this day of celebration, spears fly.

title.children: On a remote beach in Solomon Islands, family members sort out differences with spears. Another threat is proving more dangerous

image.altText: Australian Army soldiers stand at attention during an Anzac Day parade

image.altText: Origins of tuberculosis

props.synopsis: Months after a tuberculosis outbreak was confirmed in remote SA, another cluster of active TB cases has been identified in the state's Murraylands — while health authorities say the two outbreaks aren't linked, here's what we know so far.

title.children: Second TB cluster detected in SA — but what's causing the disease to spread?

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair in a pharmacist uniform smiling at the camera inside a chemist.

props.synopsis: Antibiotics to treat urinary tract infections could soon be available from SA pharmacies without a doctor's prescription — but the move has been opposed by the AMA.

image.altText: Sun setting through a line of transmission towers

props.synopsis: The NSW government is currently in talks with Origin about using taxpayer subsidies to extend the life of the plant in the state's Hunter region. It follows a review that found the state should discuss delaying the plant's closure to help prevent blackouts due to the slow building of renewables.

title.children: '$1.7b in damages a year': The estimated cost of keeping Australia's largest coal-fired power plant running

image.altText: Geoffrey Blainey makes a hand gesture while delivering a speech

props.synopsis: In an opinion piece published in The Australian, historian Geoffrey Blainey said Indigenous people were counted in every federal census since 1901. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked Geoffrey Blainey on counting Indigenous people in the census. Here's what we found

image.altText: Justice Dixon wears a dark suit jacket, white shirt and orange and blue tie and smiles closed mouthed outside the Supreme Court

image.altText: A close up of a woman in a denim jacket smiling, next to a photo of a man in a t-shirt smiling and holding a mobile phone.

title.children: The Matildas' Sam Kerr has been turned into an AI chatbot, and Mark Zuckerberg says there are 'a lot more coming'

props.synopsis: Under a massive shake-up of Defence Forces, roughly 800 army personnel will move out of Adelaide — but SA will become the home of advanced land-based, long-range strike capabilities.

title.children: Troops move out but SA becomes home of long-range strike capabilities in Defence Forces shake up

image.altText: A shirtless man about to be arrested by police on the side of a road.

props.synopsis: A South Australian CFS volunteer is found guilty of lighting the Cherry Gardens bushfire in 2021that destroyed two home and razed almost 3,000 hectares.

title.children: Former CFS volunteer found guilty of lighting Adelaide Hills bushfires

image.altText: A man sits at a table covered in drinks as he waves a cigarette in his hand.

props.synopsis: A powerful village chief invited dozens of police officers to his house for a wild party. But when one of them wound up dead, it kicked off a huge scandal that threatens the unchecked power of Thailand’s authorities.

title.children: A Thai village chief invited dozens of cops for dinner. Then he allegedly told his henchman to kill one

image.altText: A for sale sign outside a suburban home

props.synopsis: A "slight uptick" in inflation is unlikely to see the Reserve Bank lift rates at its October meeting, but households facing a fixed-rate mortgage cliff are warned to brace for higher repayments.

title.children: Half a million households brace for higher interest rates by the end of the year as the mortgage cliff looms

image.altText: A sky light pops through the grass.

props.synopsis: Designers of "earth-sheltered" homes say interest in living underground is rising as the risk of bushfires increases and more days of extreme heat are forecast.

title.children: Why more of us are opting to live underground to escape bushfires and extreme heat

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with short hair and glasses looking pensively by some bushes

props.synopsis: Some of the disability royal commission's most compelling evidence has come from mothers who lost their children. On the eve of the final report, two mums share their stories and hopes for the future.

title.children: Nella's daughter died in disability care. She wants to make sure no-one else goes through the same pain

image.altText: Danushka Gunathilaka talks to the media outside court

props.synopsis: The 32-year-old was arrested in November while in Australia for the T-20 World Cup, after he went for drinks with the woman near the Sydney Opera House before going back to her eastern suburbs home.

title.children: Cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka found not guilty of sexually assaulting Sydney woman

image.altText: Profile photo of a happy man.

props.synopsis: Irish farm worker Mark Doughty should have been boarding a flight back home in June last year, but instead the drink driver caused an accident that killed his 18-year-old work colleague.

title.children: Irish farm worker sentenced to more than eight years in prison for fatal drink driving crash

image.altText: Stack of credit cards on a black table with glass of water next to it

props.synopsis: Two men are charged after police find more than 1,000 sets of allegedly stolen bank details and pin codes, believed to be connected to a Romanian card skimming network.

title.children: More than 1,000 sets of stolen bank details found in Sydney home as part of alleged card skimming network

image.altText: An illustration of a particle and an antiparticle in purple and orange

props.synopsis: Attempts to understand why there is much more matter in the Universe than antimatter have been dealt a blow with an experiment ruling out one of the major explanations.

title.children: 'A huge puzzle': Antimatter falls just like ordinary matter, leaving the Universe's biggest mystery unsolved

image.altText: A helicopter dropping water onto a bushfire.

props.synopsis: Under the new system, parts of Australia have already faced catastrophic warnings this fire season. But some of those alerts were wrong.

title.children: Australia's new $11m fire warning system is exaggerating the risks, ABC investigation reveals

image.altText: A steam-engine train travels along, puffing steam.

props.synopsis: Police say the miniature steam-engine train derailed about 10am today, injuring several people.

title.children: Four hospitalised after miniature steam train derails at Canberra's Cockington Green Gardens

image.altText: Scarborough gas plant.

props.synopsis: Woodside's massive Scarborough gas development suffers a major blow, with the Federal Court finding an environmental plan for part of the project was not legally approved and was therefore invalid.

title.children: Woodside's Scarborough gas project dealt blow with part of its environmental plan ruled invalid

image.altText: Jacinta Allan smiles, sitting in front of an ABC microphone.

props.synopsis: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan will look to assemble her ministry, set her policy priorities and silence her opponents in her first weeks in the top job.

title.children: 'It's time, it's today': Jacinta Allan shares the moment she learnt Andrews was out

image.altText: Child in the crowd wears green and gold Matildas jersey that reads 'Kerr'

props.synopsis: Retail spending was again boosted by the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup, the latest figures show.

title.children: Retail spending continues to enjoy Matildas boost as ASX muddles along

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Statistics has also released the latest job vacancies data. Job vacancies fell by 8.9% (37,900 vacancies) in the three months to August (seasonally adjusted). It was the fifth consecutive quarterly decrease, but the level of job vacancies was still 71.5% higher than in February 2020, prior to the start of the pandemic. The ABS says the ongoing high level of vacancies reflects the continuing labour shortages in many industries. The proportion of businesses reporting at least one vacancy is continuing to decline. It fell to 21.7% in August 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Job vacancies decline again, but still elevated

children.content: The Bureau of Statistics has also released the latest job vacancies data.
Job vacancies fell by 8.9% (37,900 vacancies) in the three months to August (seasonally adjusted).
It was the fifth consecutive quarterly decrease, but the level of job vacancies was still 71.5% higher than in February 2020, prior to the start of the pandemic.
The ABS says the ongoing high level of vacancies reflects the continuing labour shortages in many industries.
The proportion of businesses reporting at least one vacancy is continuing to decline.
It fell to 21.7% in August 2023.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The rate of growth in monthly retail turnover continued to slow in August: When looking at the different segments of retail spending, food retailing and household goods retailing shrank. Spending was supported by clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing, other retailing, and cafes, restaurants and takeaway food. Altogether, it helped the total value of retail turnover increase by just 0.2 per cent. If you squint you can see it.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: August retail spending: the story in graphs

children.content: The rate of growth in monthly retail turnover continued to slow in August:
When looking at the different segments of retail spending, food retailing and household goods retailing shrank.
Spending was supported by clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing, other retailing, and cafes, restaurants and takeaway food.
Altogether, it helped the total value of retail turnover increase by just 0.2 per cent.
If you squint you can see it.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Statistics has released retail trade figures for August. They show retail turnover rose by 0.2 per cent in August, down from 0.5 per cent in July. Ben Dorber, ABS head of retail statistics, says the modest increase in retail spending shows consumers "continued to restrain their retail spending" last month. In fact, in trend terms, retail turnover rose 0.1 per cent, and was up only 1.3 per cent compared to August 2022 — the smallest trend growth over 12 months in the history of the series. "Considering how high inflation and strong population growth has added to retail turnover in the past year, the historically low trend growth highlights just how much consumers have pulled back in response to cost-of-living pressures," he said. Clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing (+1.3 per cent) recorded the largest rise, followed by cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services (+0.7 per cent), other retailing (+0.7 per cent), and department stores (+0.4 per cent). Spending was again boosted by the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup with strong demand for fan gear and increased spending across cafes, restaurants and takeaway food outlets as large crowds attended matches and live sites across the country.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail turnover up a paltry 0.2 per cent, but helped by Women's World Cup

children.content: The Bureau of Statistics has released retail trade figures for August.
They show retail turnover rose by 0.2 per cent in August, down from 0.5 per cent in July.
Ben Dorber, ABS head of retail statistics, says the modest increase in retail spending shows consumers
"continued to restrain their retail spending"
last month.
In fact, in trend terms, retail turnover rose 0.1 per cent, and was up only 1.3 per cent compared to August 2022 —
the smallest trend growth over 12 months in the history of the series.

"Considering how high inflation and strong population growth has added to retail turnover in the past year, the historically low trend growth highlights just how much consumers have pulled back in response to cost-of-living pressures," he said.

Clothing, footwear and personal accessory retailing (+1.3 per cent) recorded the largest rise, followed by cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services (+0.7 per cent), other retailing (+0.7 per cent), and department stores (+0.4 per cent).
Spending was again boosted by the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup
with strong demand for fan gear and increased spending across cafes, restaurants and takeaway food outlets as large crowds attended matches and live sites across the country.

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe raised her first to the air in front of a Central Australian road sign
